metadata.title: Causal Inference in Data Science: Doubly Robust Estimation of G-Methods | by Andrew Rothman | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: Causal Inference in Data Science: Doubly Robust Estimation of G-Methods
metadata.description: Causal Inference is a field with wide-ranging implications, from clinical trials and A/B testing to observational and natural experiments; it’s a field that touches nearly every domain and is of…

outgoing_paragraph_urls.anchor_text: Probabilistic Graphical Models: Principles and Techniques

all_paragraphs: Causal Inference is a field with wide-ranging implications, from clinical trials and A/B testing to observational and natural experiments; it’s a field that touches nearly every domain and is of interest to many practitioners including Statisticians, Machine Learning Scientists, and Computational Researchers. Recovery of unbiased estimates of Causal Effects is at times a tough task, even in Randomized settings. This task can be particularly challenging in Non-Randomized settings, requiring an array of often empirically untestable assumptions to hold that have both mathematical and philosophical implications.

In the interest of recovering an unbiased estimate of a Mean Causal Effect of an Intervention on an Outcome, there are several tools we can leverage. Under the assumption of the correct specification of a true Causal DAG, and in the case where the measured variables in the DAG are a sufficient set for conditional confounding adjustment of the Intervention-Outcome relationship (and hence provides conditional exchangeability within levels of the variables in the sufficient set), we can leverage the set of G-Methods to recover unbiased estimates of Causal Contrasts of interest. In particular, in the set of G-Methods we may be able to leverage:
When used individually, Standardization requires correct specification of the Outcome Model, with Inverse Probability Weighting requiring correct specification of the Intervention Model.

However, is there a way to combine these two approaches into a single estimation technique with more relaxed assumptions? A technique that only requires correct specification of the Outcome Model OR Intervention Model, but not both. And importantly, we need not know which model is correct, only that at least one of them is correct? This is exactly the spirit behind Doubly Robust Estimation.

In this article, we will specify a toy-example, work through the theory and mathematics behind G-Methods, specify an example Doubly Robust Estimator, and conduct an in-depth computational simulation to investigate these methods.
The formal contents of this piece are as follows:
Let us postulate a simple toy example:

We would like to recover an unbiased estimate of the causal effect of binary Intervention A on continuous Outcome Y in a non-randomized setting. Let us assume we are all-knowing and know exactly the “true” marginal Causal DAG as shown in Figure 1 (under the null hypothesis of no causal effect of A on Y).
Figure 1 specifies two common causes of both A and Y, binary variables C1 and C2. In the marginal graph there are two backdoor associational paths from A to Y, i.e. A to C1 to Y and A to C2 to Y.
A brief refresher on the connection between d-separation of a Causal DAG and independence in distribution of observed data:
In Figure 1, A and Y are clearly not marginally d-separated due to the open backdoor paths from A to Y through C1 and C2.

When exchangeability exists within levels of known and accurately measured variables in the Causal DAG, there are several approaches for “manipulating” or “adjusting” the graph to achieve d-separation. These methods can be grouped into two broad categories:
The methods of interest in this article, and those of which form the Doubly Robust Estimator discussed here, are G-Methods
We will next discuss two such G-Methods: Standardization and Inverse Probability Weighting.

Let us assume we were to leverage classical stratification-based techniques. Assume we were to condition on C1 and C2 as shown in Figure 2. In this conditional Causal DAG we have closed all backdoor paths from A and Y, leaving A and Y d-separated conditional on C1 and C2:

Under the assumption of consistency and positivity, via the Causal Markov Assumption the d-separation of A and Y conditional on C1 and C2 directly implies independence in distribution of A and Y conditional on C1 and C2, of which our observed data is a function of.
Mathematically we can express this by the following:
Given the data is drawn from joint probability distribution P, we can specify the following sampling estimator:

Notice although the mean estimates above are for counterfactual quantities, the causal contrast recovered is within levels of variables C1, C2. With the outcome model correctly specified, we could leverage the joint distribution of C1, C2 and the parametric g-formula to marginalize out C1, C2, recovering the marginal counterfactual estimates of the mean outcome under a=1 and a=0.
The above equation we refer to as Standardization with the parametric g-formula.

Note Figure 3a below, where we have specified the Causal SWIG (Single World Intervention Graph) of the Causal DAG in Figure 1. Note how we have decoupled the observed intervention A and counterfactual intervention a into separate nodes. A is the observed intervention present in the data, while a is where everyone in the population received intervention a. For further clarity, we can draw separate explicit SWIGs for our two interventions of interest, as shown in Figure 3b and Figure 3c.

Returning to our marginal Causal DAG in Figure 1, we know that Intervention A and Outcome Y are not marginally d-separated. In the previous section, we specified the outcome model with the correct functional form, and then leveraged Standardization via the parametric g-formula to recover a pseudo-population representing the Causal SWIGs in Figures 3a-c to recover unbiased estimates of the mean counterfactual outcomes if everyone in the population received intervention a=1 and everyone in the population received intervention a=0.

There is an alternative approach that also leads to a pseudo-population with the identical Causal SWIGs in Figures 3a-c as produced by Standardization. This approach involves correctly specifying the Intervention Model, and leveraging Inverse Probability Weighting (IPW) with Marginal Structural Modeling (MSM).

Bringing our attention back to Figure 2, we know that A and Y are d-separated conditional on C1 and C2, which directly implies independence in distribution of A and Y conditional on C1 and C2 by the Causal Markov Assumption:
Therefore, let’s attempt to specify the Intervention Model with these conditional variables C1 and C2:

In the previous two sections, through leveraging G-methods we recovered unbiased estimates of the mean counterfactual outcome if the entire population had received intervention a=1, and the mean counterfactual outcome if the entire population had received intervention a=0:
We recovered these mean counterfactual outcomes using two different approaches:

Note importantly however, in order for either of these two approaches to recover unbiased estimates of the mean counterfactual quantities of interest, the model specification of the statistical models need be correct.
With Standardization, we assume we correctly specify the true Outcome Model, and with Inverse Probability Weighting we assume we correctly specify the true Intervention Model:

Correct specification not only in terms of the correct variables in the model to result in d-separation of an appropriate Causal DAG or SWIG, but also the correct functional form of said models and fulfillment of any parametric assumptions with respect to estimation of (at least) model location parameters. If the model specification is incorrect, these methods are not guaranteed (and likely will not) recover unbiased estimates of the mean causal effects of interest.

Now, there are situations where due to the causal structure of the problem and available data, only Standardization or Inverse Probability Weighting are an option but not both (I will cover such an example in a future article). However, in examples like the one presented in Figure 1 where we could reasonably use either method, which should we choose? Standardization or IPW?

One option, based on our domain expertise, is to choose the method we feel most confident about. From a subject matter perspective, do we have far more confidence in our ability to correctly specify the Outcome Model over the Intervention Model, or vice-versa? If we have far more confidence in our model specification abilities with one method over the other, it could be desirable to use that method.

The above approach is reasonable; though there’s something a bit deflating about it. Instead, wouldn’t it be nice to use BOTH methods and somehow combine the results? And perhaps we can combine the methods in such a way that it works “better” than using either approach individually? This is exactly the spirit behind Doubly Robust Estimation.

The general idea behind a Double Robust Estimator is to recover estimates of the mean counterfactual quantities of interest using both Standardization and Inverse Probability Weighting, and then combine the results of the two analyses together. Importantly though, we construct a combined sampling estimator such that as long as we have the model specification of just one model correct (the Outcome Model or Intervention Model), then our sampling estimator produces unbiased estimates of the mean counterfactual quantities of interest. This is the case even if our model specification is completely wrong for one of the two models. And importantly, we need not know which of the two models is correctly specified (Outcome or Intervention model); just that at least one of them is correctly specified. Hence the name “Doubly Robust Estimator”. Colloquially speaking, we don’t put all of our eggs in one basket with one approach. Rather we “spread around the risk” and have two shots at getting the answer correct.

There are many Doubly Robust Estimators (DRE)researchers and practitioners have developed. Below is a very popular DRE that coincides with our particular problem (binary Intervention with a Continuous outcome).
Regarding the Doubly Robust Estimator, our claim is the following:
Let’s take steps to formally prove this claim.
First let’s investigate the case where the Outcome Model is correctly specified, but the Intervention Model is misspecified:
As we can see above, our claim of unbiasedness holds.
Let’s now rearrange our DRE a bit:
Let’s now investigate the case where the Intervention Model is correctly specified, but the Outcome Model is misspecified:
Again, we can see our claim of unbiasedness holds.
With our mathematical analysis of the DRE sufficiently complete, let’s next jump into the computational simulation.
We’re going to conduct a computational simulation in Python to investigate the methods described in this piece, in particular the Doubly Robust Estimator. We will:
Specify a function to simulate a dataset as the per the Causal DAG specified in Figure 4 of size n=100,000:
Note above that as per our simulated dataset, the true Mean Causal Effect Difference of A on Y is 1.23. Let’s keep this in mind as we continue through the analysis.

Let’s next specify a function, given a particular Outcome Model specification as input, to conduct Standardization via the parametric g-formula. Note the function return 95% confidence bounds around the Mean Causal Effect Difference via bootstrap estimators:
Using the known correct model specification, let’s return the results of the Standardization model and confirm it’s similar to the true Mean Causal Effect Difference:
As shown above, the correctly specified Standardization model returned a Mean Causal Effect Difference of A on Y of 1.2317. This is very similar to the true Difference of 1.23.
Let’s now purposely misspecify our Standardization model, and review the results:

The absence of variable C1 with it’s correct functional form in the Outcome Model results in Outcome Model misspecification. The results above show an estimated Mean Causal Effect Difference of A on Y of 2.175, which we know is incorrect.
Let’s now specify a function, given a particular Intervention Model specification as input, to conduct IPW via Marginal Structural Modeling:
Using the known correct model specification, let’s return the results of the Marginal Structural Model and confirm it’s similar to the true Mean Causal Effect Difference:
As shown above, the correctly specified Marginal Structural Model returned a Mean Causal Effect Difference of A on Y of 1.2276. This is very similar to the true Difference of 1.23.
Now let’s purposely misspecify the Marginal Structural Model, and review the results:

The absence of variable C1 with it’s correct functional form in the Intervention Model results in Intervention Model misspecification. The results above show an estimated Mean Causal Effect Difference of A on Y of 2.166, which we know is incorrect.

Finally, let’s specify a function to construct our Doubly Robust Estimator (DRE) as discussed in Section 6. Note the function return 95% confidence bounds around the Mean Causal Effect estimate via bootstrap estimators:
Let’s recover the DRE when both the Outcome and Intervention Model are correctly specified:
… the DRE when the Intervention Model is correctly specified, but the Outcome Model is misspecified:
… the DRE when the Outcome Model is correctly specified, but the Intervention Model is misspecified:
… and finally, the DRE when both the Outcome Model and Intervention Model are misspecified:
The results of the four DRE analyses are shown below:

As shown in the results above, the DRE returned a very good estimate of the true Mean Causal Effect Difference of A on Y of 1.23 in every case except when BOTH the Outcome and Intervention Models were misspecified.
For the complete code/notebook for the above computational simulation, please see the following github link

This concludes our explanation and working example of Doubly Robust Estimation (DRE). As already mentioned, the DRE described here is just one DRE. There are other DRE sampling estimators that have been developed for other use-case problems. I would encourage anyone who found the above material insightful to research other DREs, create there own simulation examples, leverage my code as a jump-off point, and experiment on your own!

If you would like to learn more about methods and considerations for Causal Inference, I would suggest textbooks “Causal Inference: What If” by Miguel Hernan and Jamie Robins at Harvard (two of my former Professors), “Causality” by Judea Pearl at UCLA, and “Probabilistic Graphical Models: Principles and Techniques” by Daphne Killer at Stanford and Nir Friedman at Hebrew University of Jerusalem. These are all fantastic texts. I plan on writing more in-depth pieces on Causal Inference in the future.
Probabilistic Graphical Models: Principles and Techniques

I hope the above is insightful. As I’ve mentioned in some of my previous pieces, it’s my opinion not enough folks take the time to go through these types of exercises. For me, this type of theory-based insight leaves me more comfortable using methods in practice. A personal goal of mine is to encourage others in the field to take a similar approach. I’m planning on writing based pieces in the future, so feel free to connect with me on LinkedIn, and follow me here on Medium for updates!
Your home for data science. A Medium publication sharing concepts, ideas and codes.
Principal Data/ML Scientist @ The Cambridge Group | Harvard trained Statistician and Machine Learning Scientist | Expert in Statistical ML & Causal Inference
